s.text: In the recent debates, he has left abortion and school prayer to the true believers Keyes and Bauer, and focused exclusively on the flat tax, repeating the phrase as a kind of meditational "om."
To be precise, Woodruff asked what lessons Bush took from the successes and failures of Acheson and George Marshall.

In only his second campaign, Forbes has turned into a full-fledged Harold Stassen figure--a candidate for whom unpopularity serves as some kind of weird inspiration.

But their support hasn't helped Forbes--in fact, it has made him more unelectable than ever.
The lessons of Acheson and Marshall are is that our nation's greatest export to the world has been, is, and always will be the incredible freedoms we understand in the great land called America."

The way he speaks reminds me of something I once read about the linguist Myrna Gopnik and her work on what I believe she calls "Family K." Although otherwise normally intelligent, members of Family K stumble over basic grammar, coming up with sentences like, "The boys eat four cookie."
In other instances, such as in his closing remarks, he simply recited familiar arias from his stump speech.
